_header: I am as I am and so I will be
Note:
Cf. Utley (1945)
XUtley, Francis Lee. “Wyatt as a Scottish Poet.” Modern Language Notes 60 (1945): 106-11, 106-10.
_description: The rebellious lover, attributed to Sir Thomas Wyatt — 10 monorhyming quatrains

BLAdd17492.First Lines:
I am as I am and so wilbebut how that I am none knoith
                    trulie…
BLAdd17492.Last Lines:
…I do proteste as ye maye seethat I am as I am and so will I
                    bee

Banna.First Lines:
I am as I am and so will I beBot how þat I am nane knawis
                    trewlie…
Banna.Last Lines:
…I do protest as ȝe may seThat I am as I am and so will I
                    be
Banna.Attributed Title:
Heir endis the tesment of maister andro kennedy Maid be dumbar quhen he wes
                    lyk to dy (f. 155v)

TCD160.First Lines:
…I doo not reioyse nor yet complayneboth myrth and sadnes I
                    doo refrayne…
TCD160.Last Lines:
…I do protest as ye doo sethat I am as I am and soo wyll I
                    dy

PhilUPLat35.First Lines:
I ham as I ham & so will I bebut howe I ham none knowithe
                    truly…
PhilUPLat35.Note:
16 lines added to flyleaf with burden ‘Adew
                    sewte…’.

CULDd819.Transcription: I am as I am and natt as I wold behe that wold that I were warseffull moste he thee
